issues.title: Pre-existing relationship between the Attester and the Verifier
issues.author: ysong02
issues.body:
This issue is based on Michael's comments during the adoption call of the draft (see [here](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/lake/Yivtuau5Wfm_mtsadp-l2nBXaMo/))

If we assume a pre-existing relationship between the Attester and the Verifier, there is no need to negotiate evidence formats in ead_1 and ead_2. The process can be simplified by sending Evidence directly in ead_3.
Or, optionally including a label in ead_1 to indicate that an attestation is taking place.

comments.author: ysong02
comments.body: A trigger is needed cause the Verifier needs to send a nonce for freshness guarantee.

comments.author: ysong02
comments.body: After the meeting with Göran and Mališa, we decided to support the option of sending nothing in ead_value. We will keep evidence format negotiation as the default, since, in most cases, the Verifier needs to know the format (e.g., EAT with CoSWID in CBOR) to properly decode the evidence.

issues.title: Section Assumptions need improvements
issues.author: ysong02
issues.body:
Based on Jun Zhang's comments during the adoption call, (see [here](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/lake/nqF1JP86m_bQnWD2BfZea5i16_0/)), some assumptions in the Section _Assumptions_ are too strong. In short, there is a conflict between the texts in Section _Assumptions_ and Section _Remote Attestation over EDHOC_. The case where the Verifier cannot handle the evidence format provided by the Attester is already covered in section _Remote Attestation over EDHOC_, it seems unnecessary to state in Section _Assumptions_ that "The Verifier is assumed to know how to verify multiple formats of the evidence type.".

Context: 
- Section _Assumptions_ states: “The Verifier is assumed to know how to verify multiple formats of the evidence type.” 
- Secition _Remote Attestation over EDHOC (5.2.1.1.2)_ states: “In case none of the evidence types is supported, the Relying Party rejects the first message_1 with an error indicating support for another evidence type.“

We can improve in two ways:
1. Specify that the assumption in Section _Assumptions_ regarding the Verifier’s knowledge of multiple evidence formats applies only when remote attestation is successfully completed. Additionally, consider moving the description of evidence format mismatches from Section _Remote Attestation over EDHOC_ to Section 8 _Error Handling_, for better coherence.
2. Related to #1 , if we simplify the protocol by assuming a pre-existing relationship between the Attester and the Verifier, we can eliminate the need for evidence format negotiation. In this case, we would only need to add an assumption about the pre-existing relationship in Section Assumptions, and the statement regarding multiple evidence formats could be removed entirely.

comments.author: junzhanghw
comments.body: I think  one reasonable assumption is that the verifier knows to verify some formats of evidence, but not necessarily all formats. Then you can still keep the statement of "Seciion Remote Attestation over EDHOC (5.2.1.1.2) states: “In case none of the evidence types is supported, the Relying Party rejects the first message_1 with an error indicating support for another evidence type.“"

comments.author: ysong02
comments.body: @junzhanghw I see, I think what you said is quite similar to what we have in the draft in Section Assumptions: “The Verifier is assumed to know how to verify multiple formats of the evidence type.”

comments.author: junzhanghw
comments.body:
yes. but some clarification is needed. because the verifier can know 1, 2, 3,... formats, while 1 does not count for multiple. 

Also, depending on the the dataset of the golden measurement, sometimes the verifier can decode the evidence but it cannot make the judgement of the evidence (it does not know whether the attester) is trusted or not. In such a case, you prefer to return an error, or let the internal logic of the verifier to decide the attestation result?

issues.title: Continuous attestation
issues.author: ysong02
issues.body:
How to repeat remote attestation when one wants to achieve continous assurance?
 
We currently rely on EDHOC with PSK, or simply redo the entire remote attestation process over EDHOC. 
This is an issue that should be addressed in the draft.

comments.author: ysong02

issues.title: Correct Section Error Handling
issues.author: ysong02
issues.body:
The negative attestation result should not be treated as an error in EDHOC. The evaluation of the attestation result is the responsibility of the Relying Party, which is out of scope for this draft and is determined at the application level.

What we need to address here are the cases where a remote attestation process fails due to operational errors.

For example, the following cases should be considered errors:

- The Verifier does not support the evidence format that is proposed by the Attester.
- The Verifier cannot decode the received evidence.
- The Verifier lacks necessary reference values (e.g., missing public key) and cannot evaluate the evidence.

pulls.title: addressed comments from adoption call
pulls.author: ysong02
pulls.body:
The changes are:
- Supplemente section 5.2.1.1.3 Evidence with additional content regarding the EAT token. Fixes #2 
- In section 6.1, add the support for removing evidence type negotiation when there is a pre-existing relationship between the Attester and the Verifier. Fixes #1 
- In section 4 Assumptions, add the assumption of the notion of time. Change the word _multiple_ to _at least one_ . Fixes #3
- In section 5.1.2 Network Service Attestation, expand the content with a use case.
- Add nomative language in section 5.2.1.1.4 and 5.2.2.1.4, specifying that "The ead_value **MUST** be empty".
